proof: Proof. From the previous lemma, whp $n-n_K \le ne^{-d/3}$. Also, we can write $2|E_K| \ge \sum^n D_i - 2(n-n_K)$. We have $\Delta \sim N(d - \mu, 1/n)$, thus whp $d - \mu - \frac{1}{2}e^{-d/3} < \Delta$. For $d \ge 3$, $\mu \le e^{-d/2} < e^{-d/3}$, hence $\Delta > d - \frac{3}{2}e^{-d/3}$. It is therefore enough to show that whp $\sum^n D_i \ge n(d-2e^{-d/3})$. Since the probability of $\sum D_i$ being even is bounded below by a constant, it is enough to show that whp $\text{Poisson}(\Delta n) \ge n(d-2e^{-d/3})$. Since $\Delta \ge d - \frac{3}{2}e^{-d/3}$ whp, we have from (9) that $P(\text{Poisson}(\Delta n) \le n(d-2e^{-d/3})) = e^{-\Omega(n)})$. The result for $G(n, d/n)$ follows from contiguity of $K(n, d)$.
